name: valeraldehyde
Reason: The target compound valeraldehyde consists of a pentane chain with an aldehyde functional group. The basic unit, pentane, has a melting point of -130°C. An aldehyde group generally has polar character, which provides some dipole-dipole interactions and can slightly increase the melting point relative to non-polar hydrocarbons. For example, the addition of an aldehyde group could add approximately +10°C to +20°C to the melting point of the hydrocarbon backbone. However, because the aldehyde is at the end of the chain, this polar effect on the melting point is less pronounced than if it were in the middle of the chain. Hence, we might consider a smaller effect, say +15°C as an estimation.

name: valeraldehyde
Reason: The target compound valeraldehyde consists of a pentane chain with an aldehyde functional group. The aldehyde group, due to its polarity and ability to form hydrogen bonds, typically increases the melting point relative to non-polar compounds. Pentane has a melting point of -130°C. The polar aldehyde group would increase this melting point by creating stronger intermolecular forces than the van der Waals forces in non-polar chains. However, because the polar group is at the end of the chain rather than being more centrally located, its ability to significantly raise the melting point is lessened, contributing an estimated increase of about +38°C.
